Articles.Content:
WHAT'S THIS?! SUPERWEEGEE4000 MADE A ROCKET?! YOU'RE A ROVER ENGINEER! KNOW YOUR PLACE, MAGGOT!!

Okay, okay, I am a rover engineer, but after witnessing this rocket's capabilities, I absolutely had to share it. I guess people will accept "Honorary Rocket Engineer" as a secondary title, in addition to my entirely primary job of rover engineer. I doubt I'll be releasing any more rockets - but if you have a request for a rover, feel free to let me know.

I present to you: The Sirius I Heavy Launch Vehicle.

(I'm just going to resize these images to 640x480 so Postimage will stop giving me the bird.)

The Sirius I is a massive lifter straight out of the Crazy Corner that is my brain. Every engine is a Mainsail for maximum lifting power - just keeping the throttle at one notch below max will keep them from overheating.

Why is it that all my launches have to be at night? Rrrgh....

Anyway, the Sirius I is capable of putting a Jumbo 64 into a 100 kilometer circular orbit with an incredible surplus of fuel to spare.

With such a long, heavy payload, it gets a little wobbly during the climb inside the bulk of the atmosphere. However, its flight path isn't really affected.

Gravity turn at around 10,000 meters. Standard stuff.

It is recommended that you do NOT remove the reaction wheels if you want to turn the rocket 90 degrees within the next century.

Get your apoapsis to about 100 kilometers and burn about 25 seconds beforehand. The second stage will run out of fuel at this point.

Now you're in orbit with half your third-stage fuel left. Congratulations.

You can even land it again. Below: All that survived. Oh, I can land. Just not without landing legs.

The Sirius I has not yet been weight-tested. If you possess a data readout modification such as Kerbal Engineer, feel free to take a look at its payload limit. Craft file comes with test payload (the probe core and above).

.craft: http://www./download/f6zc2a182yjzgw3/Sirius_I.craft

CEO Note: Isn't it great when your employee makes a showcase for you instead of you having to type every...single...letter? It's the little things.
